step.value: Artificial intelligence has gotten so good at mimicking human cognition that it can be jarring when it doesn’t quite work.
Sometimes AI gets it very wrong, like when autofill presents the wrong words in a text, or when Spotify pulls up a dud of a song.
But why do those glitches happen? And how are machines getting better and better at doing what our brains do?
To understand how AI works, you have to understand how human cognition works and recognize all of the processes we take for granted.
We don't think of the brain as mechanical. Cognition can seem to happen in an instant. But it actually requires a series of steps. That’s a lot like how an algorithm works.
In this interactive, we're slowing down the cognitive process to show you, step by step, how our brains work.

btn.text: How facial recognition knows who you are
How Spotify builds the perfect playlist
How autofill reads your mind when you text or email

text.value: Almost half of your brain is devoted to the visual system — and a surprising amount of brainpower is used to identify faces. Facial recognition programs try to recreate that lightning-fast human cognition. It’s a work in progress.

In a fifth of a second, your brain can decide whether a photo shows a face or some other object. Some neurons in the visual cortex — aptly called “face cells” — are dedicated solely to faces. They register different features and the spatial relationship between them.

btn.text: What we see in a face

text.value: We’re exceptionally good at recognizing faces. It takes only a fraction of a second to recognize a loved one or a celebrity.
Can you recognize this face in a flash?

If you guessed Marilyn Monroe, you got it. But it’s much harder to recognize a face if you take away a feature. That’s because, to your brain, a face is not a single object, but a combination of features. Most important are the eyes, mouth, and — surprisingly — eyebrows.
Can you recognize this face without eyebrows?
Here’s the same person’s face, but with no features removed.
Now can you guess who this is?
If you guessed Kim Kardashian, you’re right. Though she was missing a feature, your brain still knew it was looking at a face.

But when a face is upside down, the face-recognizing cells have trouble. Key landmarks are out of place, so your brain has to draw on other parts of its visual cortex. Upside-down faces confuse AI, too. One computer thought an upside-down image of Kardashian was another celebrity entirely.
Can you guess who?
Talk about a crazy train! An upside-down photo of Kim Kardashian confuses AI so much, it thinks it’s looking at Ozzy Osbourne.

Like the brain, facial recognition software identifies features and measures the distance between them. Often, it’s better than humans. People can recognize about 5,000 faces. AI can learn millions and identify them in moments.
But while the human brain can work around a missing feature, AI has more trouble. Here’s what a computer guessed it was seeing when shown confusing images.

But AI is only as good as its training — and upside-down photos aren’t the biggest risk. Facial recognition algorithms have been trained largely on photos of white men, so they make more mistakes identifying dark-skinned people, especially women.

Police departments across the world are testing facial recognition software. Researchers at the University of Essex found that a trial by the London metropolitan police made false identifications 80 percent of the time. Will AI ever be accurate enough to avoid false arrests?

btn.text: Discover more about AI and the brain

text.value: When you listen to someone speak, your brain makes educated guesses about what’s coming next. Artificial intelligence uses a similar process to predict the words you’ll text next on your phone.

speech.title: This word could save your life

text.value: Early human brains adapted to connect speech with sensory events. It was a matter of survival: Anticipating the next word could save precious seconds in life-or-death situations. It’s hard to pick the “right” word without context.

To make the right connections, specific neurons in the brain’s auditory cortex evolved to respond to different phonemes — small units of sound such as “f,” “t,” or “th.” Those groups of neurons learn the possible relationships between sounds to predict what might come next.
What word comes next?

To predict text, AI also tries to understand the relationships between words. The messaging app on iPhones and Gmail’s Smart Compose feature try to guess the next word you’ll type. They do that by learning the correlations among letters, words, and sentences through training on millions of documents.

As you type, iPhone’s AI offers three possible choices for the next word in the sequence. Every iPhone user will get different suggestions, learned from language patterns in that person’s message history.
Take a look at the image. Can you guess which three words AI suggested for one user?

Sometimes, cultural connotations trump logic, and AI doesn’t get it. Consider this classic catchphrase from “Saturday Night Live.” One of these words is the punchline. Three are incorrect answers, suggested by AI. Do you know the right word?

btn.text: Next: When AI gets it wrong

speech.title: How AI learns the worst from us

text.value: AI can learn human biases. Google Translate used to turn the Turkish phrase “O bir doktor” into “He is a doctor,” though “o” is a gender-neutral pronoun. Why? The algorithm trained on old documents and saw more examples of doctors identified as men. Humans corrected the AI, which now offers both a “he” and “she” translation.
But AI can also help humans function better. People with dyslexia, who struggle to read at speed and predict the words that come next, can use AI-assisted tools to fix spelling errors.[a]

Since AI can autofill words, could it create entire texts? A cutting-edge language model, GPT-2, can write full paragraphs and stories after getting a short prompt. Some of the text it creates can be a little wonky, but plenty of it reads like a person wrote it. Its creators aren’t releasing all the details behind the technology, concerned that it could be used to automate trolling or create fake news. [b][c][d][e]

text.value: From lullabies to wedding hymns to funeral dirges, music is bound up with emotion. But what makes a song feel right for a moment or mood? Your brain learns, over time, how to pick the perfect song based on your past reactions to music. Spotify and other AI-driven music services start similarly but add a lot more to build customized playlists.

music.title: Are my sad songs sadder than yours?

text.value: The human brain is hard-wired to make sense of music — which is why though some perceptions of music are cultural, others are universal. Researchers asked members of the Mafa, a Cameroon tribe with no exposure to Western culture, to listen to pop songs. Most of the Mafa correctly labeled the songs happy, sad, or fearful, even without understanding the words.

music.title: If you’re happy and you know it...

text.value: Drag the slider to show where this music falls on a scale from happiest to saddest.

You might innately sense that a song is happy, but AI has to be taught. Machines measure mood with a metric called “valence.” The higher the valence, the happier the song. Spotify hires music experts to teach its AI the valence of some songs. That training becomes an algorithm, which the AI then applies to other songs on the platform.
Here’s how your answers compared to Spotify’s valence measurements.

music.title: An AI playlist just for you

text.value: To put together a Discover Weekly playlist for you, Spotify’s AI compares music you’ve listened to with songs you might not have heard. (It adds extra rules in hard code, like no Christmas music after December 25.) It also looks at a song’s valence, time signature, key, tempo, and “danceability” — a metric based on tempo, rhythm stability, and beat strength.
Where does this music fall on a scale from least to most danceable?
Here’s how your answers compared to Spotify’s valence measurements.

Another Spotify metric compares your listening history to those of other users. If you and a friend have similar tastes, perhaps you’ll like her new favorite song. Another tool trawls the internet for text about songs in news articles and blogs. The platform also considers playlists put together by casual listeners and professionals hired by Spotify.

The most popular Spotify playlist, RapCaviar, owes its popularity to a handful of people putting 50 or so songs together every week. Nearly 12 million people follow the playlist, which has launched careers and helped singles get millions of streams. Tastemakers still inform the algorithms, not the other way around.[f]
Why AI sometimes gets it wrong

music.title: The right data, the wrong song

text.value: Even with all this data, the Spotify recommendation engine sometimes offers you a song you hate. That’s because Spotify focuses on technical elements, but doesn’t know the context — a break-up, a bad memory, a pet peeve. Ultimately, taste isn’t perfectly predictable.

Spotify is fun, but music is more important to us than we realize. The brain is actually hard-wired to make sense of music: Parts of the auditory cortex respond to music-like sounds, but not to speech or non-musical noises. That’s why we often remember song lyrics from decades ago, while forgetting old conversations.

According to recent research, the part of the brain that responds to music remains active in patients with Alzheimer’s. Music that was meaningful to a person can even pull him or her out of the haze for a short while. Music moves us through time, bringing memories into vivid relief.
